title: feat: add top-level docs example.
body:
This commit adds a top-level example to the crate docs, and also fixes
a broken link in the docs for ObjectType.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

title: feat: Minor cleanup of docs and trait defs.
body:
This commit marks the contents of the HashAlgorithm and ObjectType
traits as hidden, because their internals are _only_ relevant to the
internals of `GitOid`. The trait is sealed, so it can't be implemented
by other types, and the types that _do_ implement it aren't able to be
constructed (no public constructor + private field).

This also moves all exported items to the top level, so there are no
public submodules. The API of the crate is quite small, so it's nice
for users to have all the docs accessible from one place.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

title: feat: Add async constructors for GitOid.
body:
This commits adds two new constructors for `GitOid` to build new
GitOIDs from async readers, with or without an expected length
being provided.

This was pretty easy! I've generally stayed away from doing async
things because of the general vibe that it's kinda finicky / difficult.
I'm happy this was so simple to do.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

title: feat: simplify GitOid crate substantially.
body:
This commit comments out the FFI for the GitOid crate, which
will be repurposed into an FFI for the OmniBOR crate. This will avoid
a known issue with cbindgen involving macro expansion of crates used
as dependencies in the same workspace, and will also more directly
reflect our intended use of the code in this workspace anyway. We want
to provide a basis for cross-language OmniBOR implementations, not
really for cross-language GitOID implementations, for which libgit2
should already be fine.

This commit also simplifies the trait bounds on the GitOID type, and
modifies some existing imports from `std` to `core`.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

title: feat: Windows test, FFI test, and commit msg CI
body:
This commit improves the CI configuration by:

- Adding testing for Windows
- Adding testing for CCI code on Ubuntu and Windows
- Adding checking for conventional commit format in commit messages
- Upgrading from checkout v2 to v4 across the board.

title: fix: Windows FFI mistakenly using BufReader
body:
Another commit fixing a Windows-specific issue. This
time that the BufReader import was removed, and Unix
uses of it in the FFI code were removed, but not for
Windows code, causing compilation failure on Windows.

This commit fixes the issue.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

title: fix: Fixed broken FFI code on Windows.
body:
Haha this is why we need Windows CI jobs. A prior
commit missed updating two function calls in the
Windows FFI code, causing compilation issues. This
commit fixes it.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

title: feat: Simplify GitOid trait bounds
body:
Turns out the prior bounds were more complicated than
they needed to be. H::OutputSize works instead of
<H as OutputSizeUser>::OutputSize.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

title: feat: improved gitoid_from_buffer, misc. fixups
body:
This commit does a few things:

- Refactors gitoid_from_buffer to delegate to BufReader.
- Uses format_bytes::format_bytes instead of format to construct
  prefix for hashing.
- Adds GitOid::from_reader_with_expected_length to support
  non-Seek-able readers and avoid cost of seeking if length is
  already known.
- Adds GITOID_URL_SCHEME constant to replace two uses of
  literal string and ensure they're always consistent.
- Updates FFI to support new from_reader_with_expected_length
- Updates FFI to avoid double-buffering when building a GitOid
  from a reader, since the underlying implementation buffers.
- Adds FFI support for new from_reader_with_expected_length
  constructor.
- Renames FFI constructor from _new_from_* to _from_*, and
  updates C test code to use the new prefix.

title: feat: rewrite docs intro, reorg docs slightly
body:
This commit rewrites the introductory docs for the crate,
and also reorganizes some docs for FFI and hashes slightly
to be clearer / cleaner. FFI is no longer marked doc(hidden),
and the contents of crate::ffi::gitoid have been re-exported
to appear under crate::ffi directly. This isn't _really_ that
important since they're only intended to be called from C
code anyway, but at least this way they appear in the Rust
docs and are easier to find.

title: Implement ArtifactID type.
body:
This initial commit just defines an artifact ID type that selects
the specific construct of the GitOid type.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

title: Shortened GitOid constructor names.
body: This commit shortens constructor names to make code a little easier to parse visually.

title: Misc. cleanups and fixes.
body:
The commit does a few things:

- Deletes the builder (it's extra complexity for minimal benefit)
- Deletes the HashRef type in favor of methods directly
  on GitOid.
- Slightly reorganizes imports to be cleaner / clearer.
- Manually impls traits on GitOid because the derives
  were silently not working.
- Makes the ObjectType trait sealed

Plus a few other little cleanup changes.

title: Make `GitOid` generic over the underlying hash output size.
body:
This commit redesigns the implementation of the `GitOid` type,
changing the underlying buffer from one designed to fit the largest
possible hash algorithm _supported_ by the crate regardless of the
actual hash algorithm used in a specific case, to one that is sized
to have exactly the space needed for the selected hash algorithm.

This involves a little bit more complexity than I'd like, because Rust's
const-generics support is still incomplete and thus this crate
relies on the `generic_array` crate to provide what we need. In the
future we'd replace this with normal const-generic arrays which
would (hopefully) also simplify the bounds on the generic types.

This commit does not complete the work for this transition, as it
does not address fixing the FFI story. The FFI module is commented
out, and will need to be updated before this can be merged.

This commit _does_ remove the finder API. After consideration,
I think the current API for finding matching GitOids is both too
complicated in terms of trait bounds AND under-powered in terms
of controlling matching behavior. It may not even make sense to
proscribe _how_ matching can be performed on a scale beyond
"check object against GitOid" given the complexities of performance
tuning which are possible.

A fun note on sizing, in the prior code the size of a GitOid was fairly
large, as the GitOid type had to store two 4 byte enums (HashAlgorithm
and ObjectType) plus a "usize" (usually 4 bytes), and a 32-byte buffer.
So it would generally be 52 bytes.

In the new code, for SHA-256, GitOids are 33 bytes (1 byte for the
ObjectType, and 32 bytes for the buffer), and for SHA-1 GitOids are
21 bytes (1 byte for the ObjectType, 20 bytes for the buffer). Given that
we expect code using GitOids in OmniBOR to be using large numbers of
them, this size saving is great news!

Fixes #82.

title: feat: first draft of README rewrite
body:
This commit rewrites the README to more clearly explain
the background and goals of OmniBOR and of the Rust
implementation.

Right now it delegates info to crate-specific
READMEs which haven't been written yet. So there's more
work to do prior to merge. We also
need to at least publish a placeholder omnibor crate to crates.io.

title: Update devcontainer.json
body: Added cbindgen install

title: feat: Remove BufReader req for GitOid construction
body:
Previously we required buffering when constructing a GitOid
from a file, but this isn't always desirable. This commit makes
the API generic over any reader, and also updates the FFI to
make buffering optional.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>

Closes #79

title: Initial steps toward making `std` an optional feature.
body: This addresses part of #20.

title: Miscellaneous improvements
body:
This PR incorporates a variety of improvements, mostly to the `gitoid` crate. I did try to give meaningful commit messages to each to make it easier to review. If/when this is merged, we'll also want to publish a new version of the `gitoid` crate, and then probably yank the broken-on-Windows versions, and update the `omnibor` crate to depend on the new version.

Closes #61.

title: Rewrite README for clarity and project rename.
body:
This change does a couple of things:

- Rewrites the README to no longer include any references to GitBOM, and instead use the new OmniBOR name throughout.
- Adds new sections for the license and contributing information.
- Simplifies the "use from other languages" information, and removes the "adding `NUM_HASH_BYTES`" material which, as far as I can tell, is no longer required (at least, running `cbindgen` on the hosts I have on hand always include `NUM_HASH_BYTES` automatically).
- More generally, rewrites the language to be clearer about what this project is and what benefits it is intended to offer in the software supply chain space.

__Edit__: [Rendered](https://github.com/omnibor/omnibor-rs/blob/8ca4c661793366251df3b9fd732d2c841d71f1bc/README.md)

body: Signed-off-by: Nell Shamrell <nellshamrell@gmail.com>

title: re-ordering the gcc command to make it work on Ubuntu
body: Signed-off-by: Nell Shamrell <nellshamrell@gmail.com>

title: increments gitoid crate version number
body: Signed-off-by: Nell Shamrell <nellshamrell@gmail.com>

title: Adds FFI to the main branch
First draft of a finder implementation
body:
This commits adds a new `Finder` struct which matches different sources of `GitOid`s against a known set of `GitOid`s, returning both an identifier and the matching `GitOid` itself, along with reporting any errors that arise when resolving the new `GitOid`s.

The docs for the `Finder` struct spell it out the clearest. This design is centered around the new `IntoIdentifiedGitOid` trait, which is implemented for a variety of existing types. The goal of this is to allow the `Finder` to be generic over things which produce `GitOid`s, so that, for example, someone could add a mechanism to resolve `GitOid`s from a `Url` without changing any existing code.

Signed-off-by: Andrew Lilley Brinker <alilleybrinker@gmail.com>
